text: Dogs have much more sensitive noses and ears than humans, but have trouble distinguishing red from green.
The grapefruit was described as the 'forbidden fruit' in 1750.
Vitamin E was named 'tocopherol' as it was identified as essential for live births in rats.
Nearly 300 construction workers showed up at 8 am to continue building Chernobyl Reactors 5 and 6, despite the Chernobyl disaster earlier that day.
The distant horse relative Palaeotherium was first misidentified as an amphibious animal, then as a canine.
Coscinodon lawianus is one of only two species of moss found only in continental Antarctica.
A 'mystery eruption' cooled the Northern Hemisphere in 1453.
The 1925 Tri-State tornado was the deadliest in United States history.
Brachyrhaphis roseni and B. rhabdophora fish are difficult to breed because they voraciously eat their own young.
Only two people are known to have seen Du Toit's torrent frog alive.
The comet C/1975 T2 (Suzuki–Saigusa–Mori) was independently discovered by five observers within the span of half an hour.
1,10-decanediol could potentially hamper the production of nitrite in soil.
The unique flower shape of Lilium lophophorum is adapted to protect its reproductive organs from the harsh ultraviolet light and torrential rains of its habitat.
The flowers of the desert paintbrush (Castilleja chromosa) are small, green, and unremarkable.
A hypothesized land bridge (GAARlandia) may have allowed some fish species to migrate from South America to Cuba.
Debris fallout from a violent 2011 tornado included a photograph found 353 km (219 mi) downstream from its origin.
The small flowers that give Aquilegia parviflora its name make it unpopular with gardeners.
A species of Australian ant (Camponotus inflatus) has special workers that make honey, and is considered a delicacy by Aboriginal Australians.
An ancient Egyptian pet cemetery included a Rüppell's fox, a Barbary falcon, and over 500 cats.
Debris was carried aloft to an altitude of 30,000 feet (9,100 m) after the 1957 Ruskin Heights tornado.
The bacterium Ethanoligenens harbinense can produce hydrogen.
The 2007 Greensburg tornado had ten smaller tornadoes (satellite tornadoes) orbiting it.
An official investigation found the Fukushima nuclear accident was foreseeable and preventable.
A study of people who reported experiences of alien abduction found that many exhibited characteristics consistent with fantasy-prone personality.
The Chapline columbine is generally considered a distinct species, except in Texas, where it is considered a variety of the golden columbine.
Aquilegia barykinae is likely more closely related to other species of columbine than to Aquilegia amurensis, which shares its range.
More than one hundred million stars are visible in NASA's 'Zooming In on the Andromeda Galaxy' image.
Due to the near-miss effect, gamblers may mistake a game of luck for a game of skill.
According to the author of 'Stuff Matters', holding a sample of an aerogel is 'like holding a piece of sky'.
The fishing cat mainly inhabits wetlands and preys predominantly on fish.
The Trilobite Wilderness is so rich in trilobite fossils that in places virtually every rock contains a fossil.
Although the plant species Dolichostachys elongata was first described in 1962, it was not considered validly published until 60 years later.
Geologist Gilbert Wilson was the fifth Wilson at school, so he was known as 'Quintus'.
Maria Muntañola Cvetković became one of Yugoslavia's first experts on microfungi after fleeing to Argentina as a Spanish Civil War refugee.
Some Idaho mountain deathcamas are pollinated by carrion and flesh flies rather than bees.
The Australian spider Progradungula barringtonensis has been called a 'ghost of Gondwana'.
Diverse fields study the mind, including psychology, neuroscience, cognitive science, and philosophy.
Sammy Basso was the oldest known person with progeria.
1977's Typhoon Thelma was the most destructive event in Taiwan since World War II.
When the E-Defense earthquake shake table was commissioned in 2005, it was the world's largest 3D earthquake shake table.
A screen based on the circuitry of a rat brain is displayed on the façade of the Jerusalem-based Edmond and Lily Safra Center for Brain Sciences.
The Indonesian pulp and paper industry collectively controls over 10 million hectares of land.
Methuselah the lungfish likes belly rubs.
Neurocysticercosis has been referred to as 'the great imitator' because it can mimic many other neurological disorders.
Rabbits can control their body temperature with their ears.
Approximately 85 per cent of Welsh children were not in school in 1821.
In fiction, neutron stars harbour exotic lifeforms in their vicinity, on their surface, and even in their interior.
Xiphophorus signum is the only swordtail fish not known to hybridise with other species.
Many people who recover from tuberculosis lose more than half of their lung capacity.
Chronic pain syndromes affect approximately 20 percent of people and account for 15 to 20 percent of doctor visits.
Actinote zikani is one of only two butterflies on the IUCN's list of the 100 most threatened species.
Despite having no university training, Agnes Crane described a new species of brachiopod in 1886.
A tornado near Chicago was produced by a storm with a hydrodynamical helicity four times higher than the threshold favorable for tornadogenesis.
Researchers speculate that cocoa butter forms crystals on sugar while chocolate is tempered.
The number 1 is its own square, square root, and factorial.
Pituamkek National Park Reserve, Canada's newest national park, protects a chain of barrier islands that have been used for fishing and hunting by the Mi'kmaq for 4,000 years.
The Palace Theater light bulb has been running since 1908.
In 1888, a sensational story claimed that James Wickham, a British scientist, introduced two whales to the Great Salt Lake in an attempt to start a whale oil industry.
The first dogs in space (Dezik and Tsygan) returned to Earth with a parachute.
Almost 45 percent of Taiwan's beer purchases come from rechao (stir-fry) restaurants.
Public health measures and advances in medical science in modern human history helped raise global life expectancy from about 31 years in 1900 to over 66 years in 2000.
English amateur geologist Charlotte Eyton wrote a number of papers and pamphlets on the geology of the Wrekin, Shropshire, between 1862 and 1870.
Trembleuse cups and saucers enabled people with unsteady hands to drink hot beverages.
The release of the top-level domain .zip was condemned by cyber-security experts.
In 1967, two mathematicians published PhD dissertations independently disproving the same thirteen-year-old conjecture (the common fixed point problem).
International adult figure skating champion Naz Arıcı learned to skate at the age of 29.
French soldiers interred in Bayonet Trench were popularly believed to have been buried alive with their rifles in their hands.
The Adoration of the Magi in the Snow, recently re-dated, is now known to be the earliest of Bruegel's snow paintings.
Heavy spring rains caused a poor harvest of the Dickinson pumpkin, leading to a canned pumpkin shortage for Christmas in 2015.
A. krampus (a species named after the mythological Krampus) has been found living in southeastern Brazil.
The Christmas carp traditionally swims in a bathtub for a few days before becoming Christmas Eve dinner.
The 2022 Andover tornado injured only three people, despite damaging more than 1,000 buildings.
Entitativity refers to how 'groupy' a group is.
Tjeerd van Andel was surprised to find heaps of giant clam shells around hot springs on his first dive to the Pacific ocean floor.
The Mingxing Film Company released more than 150 films in 16 years, but most are now lost.
The main cemetery of Mainz was established in 1803 and became the model for the Cimetière du Père-Lachaise in Paris.
Bob Hobman recreated a possible sea journey by Palaeolithic humans after 130,000-year-old tools were found on the island of Crete.
Aucklanders have a reputation for making false earthquake reports on New Zealand's earthquake monitoring website GeoNet.
The God of Amiens (a Gaulish deity sculpture) seems to have lost his serpent.
Soviet atrocities against prisoners of war during World War II included the murder of tens of thousands of Polish soldiers in the Katyn massacre.
Coconut cups were believed to have medical benefits.
The world's oldest timepiece with an anchor escapement is in the collection of the Irish Museum of Time.
50 Lan occupied the number-one spot in Taiwan's bubble tea market for most of 2023.
The suppression of the Diaspora Revolt of 115–117 CE led to the near-total annihilation and displacement of Jewish communities in Cyrenaica, Cyprus, and much of Egypt.
An enigmatic ancient site deep in Madagascar (Teniky) may have been built by Zoroastrians.
Kent Brushes have supplied their products to every British monarch since George IV.
Crab is served in school meals in Toyama Prefecture, Japan.
Canadian microbiologist Patricia Taylor helped American diplomats hide in her house in Tehran during the Iran hostage crisis.
A 'glomping circle' in 2008 reportedly lasted seven hours.
The Holy See has been represented by an anime-style mascot named Luce.
China was once the 'Kingdom of Bicycles'.
Ryusei Nishioka broke the world record difficulty score in trampoline gymnastics by performing seven triple somersaults.
Mark IV was the first commercial software to cross $10 million in total sales, and the first to cross $100 million as well.
Lukken, a traditional dessert waffle from West Flanders, gets its name from the Dutch word for 'luck'.
The 1827 novel 'A Voyage to the Moon' contains the first use of anti-gravity for space travel in science fiction.
Capote Falls is the highest waterfall in Texas, and the only location where Hinckley's columbine occurs in the wild.
Tyromancy is a form of fortune-telling using cheese.
A recurrent famine (Kere) has haunted Madagascar's southern regions since the 1930s.
The U.S. Air Force considered a bomber version of the F-22 Raptor known as the FB-22.
During the colonial period, the Dutch East Indies was the third-largest exporter of tea after the British Raj and Ceylon.
Feelies (tactile game accessories) have been used for everything from copy protection to sexual roleplay.
The Eoscorpius, despite living hundreds of millions of years ago, has been noted for its similarity to modern scorpions.
Specimens of Aquilegia daingolica were collected in 1906 and 1909, but it was first described as a new species in 2013.
The limited study of the Afghani plants Aquilegia gracillima, A. maimanica, and A. microcentra has been blamed on political circumstances.
A long-legged lovebird (Agapornis longipes) lived in humanity's cradle (Cradle of Humankind).
Matthew Webb died attempting to swim down the Niagara Rapids.
The backflip ban in figure skating was lifted in 2024 alongside other 'somersault type jumps'.
The death rate from adrenal crises can reach as high as 6 percent.
L'Attaque, the board game that became Stratego, was patented in 1908 by its designer, a 57-year-old woman (Hermance Edan).
The Australian Light Weight Air Warning Radar was once loaded using canoes and later manhandled up a 200-foot cliff.
Ferrari FF was, upon its release, the world's fastest four-seater car.
The first silver dollars of the Republic of China were crudely designed mementos.
Deep Cut Gardens in New Jersey contains a stone replica of Mount Vesuvius that once erupted smoke at the behest of mobster Vito Genovese.
The Haitian Revolution began when Cécile Fatiman sacrificed a black pig, a ritual later repeated by Haitians resisting foreign occupation.
While the objects on the Farnese Artemis had initially been identified as female breasts, the museum housing the statue now describes them as bull scrotums.
In the history of fisheries in the Philippines, the once-dominant local municipal fisheries were supplanted first by commercial fisheries, and then by aquaculture.
The center squeeze voting phenomenon has been blamed for costing Gary Johnson the 2016 US presidential election.
An ancient Canadian archaeological site (GhGk-63) was discovered during the construction of a dump.
A Cretan man found a 1st-century statue of Aphrodite (Aphrodite Rhithymnia) while trying to drill a well, and then reburied it.
The water of Asik-Asik Falls comes from a source inside a cliff.
Blue Mountain Pottery wares had a distinctive drip glaze, particularly blue-green and black, so that each piece was unique.
Among the Orang Asli of Negeri Sembilan, chica (Johannesteijsmannia lanceolata palm) is only collected during kenduri rituals.
In 1825, the Suquamish leader Kitsap led an alliance of tribes stretching from the Columbia River to Puget Sound to stop the Cowichan slave raids wreaking havoc on the Sound.
Samuel Barber said that he could not adequately play his own Piano Sonata.
Researchers want Hymenophyllum axsmithii rhizomes so that they can tell whether the filmy fern was up a tree.
The Niederdollendorf stone, the Grésin plaque, and the Landelinus buckle are each controversially conjectured to depict a pagan-inspired Jesus Christ.
A small golden bell found at the site of the Mount Gerizim Temple is believed to have been part of the ephod of a high priest, as described in Exodus 28.
The Italian Campaign of 1796–1797 demonstrated that Napoleon was a 'great strategist'.
Oxford is the first city in the United Kingdom to adopt a zero emission zone.
Tudor Arghezi, 'perhaps the strongest personality in all of 20th-century Romanian literature', claimed that he could identify people with cancer by their smell.
A lake at the John Deere World Headquarters is used for air conditioning.
The 'Dragon Cartel', a cooperation of Chinese triads and Mexican cartels, poach fish maw in the Gulf of California and smuggle it to China.
Cyclone Hudhud caused a 60-percent decrease in the population of birds in Visakhapatnam.
Environmental destruction can be a means of genocide (genocide-ecocide nexus).
Remains from the largest rodent in history were found in Uruguay.
Thomas Edison made talking dolls.
Cave mollies (Poecilia mexicana) thrive in an environment full of hydrogen sulfide, which is lethal to most animals.
Harry S. Truman declined a mayor's suggestion to fire a nuclear bomb at a hurricane.
Eugene Parker described the mathematics behind his theory of solar wind as just 'four lines of algebra'.
Papyrus Bingen 45 may contain a word handwritten by Cleopatra.
Male and female specimens of Skimmia japonica were once thought to belong to different species.
The snail Physella acuta can twist its shell by up to 120 degrees to defend itself against predators.
The Toffee Crisp manufacturer once made a 10-kilogram (22 lb) version.
An ancient amulet discovered in Horvat Rimmon bears a love charm in which its owner invokes angels to make another person love him.
The broadspotted molly males are exploited for their sperm by a female-only species.
Some Lake Superior agates have circular, concentric rings on their surfaces, called 'eyes'.
Dinosaur tracks near Lommiswil were studied with a helicopter.
The coconut may have bisexual flowers.
The unusual wing pattern of the moth Epiphryne verriculata allows it to camouflage on dead Cordyline leaves.
Many women with polycystic ovary syndrome grow hair in a 'male' pattern, including facial hair.
Cecil Kent Drinker published his report on the Radium Girls only after a forged version was submitted in his name.
The Chandigarh chair gained recognition in the West after European dealers displayed discarded chairs bought from the local government 'for peanuts'.
Willemstad pupfish seemingly do not run out of food regardless of how many of them there are.
The Siderian is currently the earliest internationally recognized geological period.
The Indian emperor Jahangir commissioned a painting depicting his superiority over his rival, the Shah of Iran.
Eratosthenes, the librarian of the Great Library of Alexandria, was nicknamed 'Beta' ('Second') because he wasn't considered the best at anything.
People sometimes experience short-term memory loss when they walk through doorways or switch tasks (event perception).
Akari light sculptures were designed by Isamu Noguchi because a Japanese mayor asked him to revitalize the dying paper-lantern industry.
The freighters James H. Reed and Frank E. Vigor sank in separate collisions on Lake Erie on the same day.
The opening of The Empire Brunei was timed to help create hotel capacity in Brunei for an APEC summit.
German colonists were unable to win a war that they started with an unprovoked massacre (Hornkranz massacre).
Leon Trotsky frequented a Jewish dairy restaurant in the Bronx but refused to tip, and the waiters retaliated by spilling hot soup on him.
Neurocysticercosis has been referred to as the 'great imitator' because it can mimic many other neurological disorders.
Chocolate is included as an ingredient in 18th-century Italian recipes for pappardelle, fried liver, black polenta, and lasagna sauce.
As of 1.06 billion years ago, three supermassive black holes from a trio of galaxies in the constellation of Cancer were colliding.
Although J1407b eclipsed V1400 Centauri in 2007, nobody noticed for over three years.
The small fish species Poecilia vandepolli solves food shortage problems by eating its own offspring (filial cannibalism).
Cyclone Freddy was the longest-lasting tropical cyclone recorded.
Shortly after it was completed, the Tokamak de Fontenay-aux-Roses burned a hole through itself in a plasma disruption.
During the Panic of 1907, the presidents of New York City's banks and trust companies were locked in the Pierpont Morgan Library.
In 1253 Henry III of England ordered that his white bear be permitted to swim and hunt in the River Thames.
Kim Jong Il had Italian chefs flown into Pyongyang to introduce pizza to North Korea.
The leaves of Premna microphylla are used to make a green jelly called Guanyin tofu.
The concept of genocide was introduced in the 1944 book Axis Rule in Occupied Europe.
The flag of Rwanda depicts the sun illuminating the country's vegetation.
An airplane crash survivor used stroboscopic photography techniques pioneered by Doc Edgerton to take high-speed photographs of bullets, insects, and liquid drops.
Dominant males of Perugia's limia may be so preoccupied with fighting each other that the females end up mating with the subordinate males.
A Stegosaurus fossil (Apex) sold for $44.6 million.
The discovery of Laquintasaura challenged the idea that early dinosaurs could not survive in equatorial regions.
Thousands of crocodiles were once farmed on Bazaruto Island.
Doc Edgerton created a stroboscope that he used to take high-speed photographs of bullets being shot, insects flying, and drops of liquid.
The flowers of Pavonia praemorsa bloom and die within the same day.
São Tomé and Príncipe was popularly known as the Chocolate Islands in the early 1900s, when it was the world's top exporter of cocoa.
The five stripes of the flag of Togo represent the country's five regions.
Apollo astronauts walked on walls (Reduced Gravity Walking Simulator) before walking on the Moon.
On top of being used as a culinary herb, Tulbaghia acutiloba has traditionally been used in treating infectious diseases and hypertension.
The two victims of the Zénith balloon incident are depicted holding hands on their tomb.
A shipwreck in the eastern Mediterranean, dating from the Late Bronze Age, is the earliest deep-sea shipwreck to be discovered.
Johann Joseph Dömling suggested in 1803 that venous blood contained carbon monoxide.
Researchers estimated that training the model for ChatGPT used the equivalent energy footprint of 'driving 123 gasoline-powered passenger vehicles for a year'.
The 4,000-year-old Ravenswood standing stone now lies in a cul-de-sac in a 1970s Scottish housing estate.
Choco Togo produces heat-resistant chocolate bars that can withstand temperatures of up to 35 °C (95 °F).
Japanese surgeon Hayari Miyake cured Albert Einstein of a tropical fever.
Islands are home to an estimated 41 percent of land vertebrates at risk of extinction.
The Poozeum holds fossilized dinosaur feces which may have come from a T. rex.
John S. McCain Sr. and John S. McCain Jr. were the first father-and-son pair to achieve the U.S. rank of four-star admiral.
Entomologist Charles De Geer made all the illustrations for his eight-volume work himself.
The Advanced Tactical Fighter program resulted in the F-22 Raptor.
Panamanian earth scientist Erika Podest uses remote sensing to see how climate change has affected global soil moisture.
Lionel Haward applied an early example of offender profiling to help identify high-ranking Nazis disguised as ordinary troops.
Alexander Langmuir created the Epidemic Intelligence Service to send epidemiologists across the world.
Residents reported the first cycling club in Washington, D.C., to the police over concerns that bicycles posed a danger to pedestrians.
Hannibal von Degenfeld played the leading role in establishing the Bavarian Army in 1682, before leading it to the Battle of Vienna a year later.
The Piano Quintet by Dmitri Shostakovich has been called 'the most expensive piece of chamber music ever composed'.
British physician John H. Bryant gave the first description of a blue scrotum caused by a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.
The discovery of a coffin belonging to Ahhotep I, which had been reused to bury a high priest, ignited a debate among scholars over the true number of Egyptian queens named Ahhotep.
Giorgina Reid patented a technique for holding up banks (erosion prevention on coastal banks).
Niall Ó Glacáin, an Irish physician, worked as a travelling plague doctor in southern France in the 1620s.
Queen Anne Pool opened to the public one day late, after a thermostat glitch accidentally heated the pool to 100 °F (38 °C).
The first cycling club in Washington, D.C. was reported to police over concerns that bicycles posed danger to pedestrians.
The National Hospital Service Reserve trained volunteers to carry out first aid in the aftermath of a nuclear or chemical attack.
Goethe used his unrequited love to Maximiliane Brentano as inspiration for his novel The Sorrows of Young Werther.
The cupola of Homer House is part of a 19th-century cooling system.
The surviving copies of the Kitab-ı Bahriye contain a total of more than 5,700 maps.
The September 11 Digital Archive argues that even its misinformation is useful to the historical record.
The Free Universal Construction Kit connects ten otherwise incompatible children's construction toys.
Estimates of the boost to the British fashion industry by Catherine, Princess of Wales, range from £152 million to £1 billion per year.
A committee rejected six designs for the National Baseball Hall of Fame commemorative coins before approving a seventh, which was sketched during the meeting.
The Zoninus collar is the only known Roman slave collar that offers a reward for returning its wearer.
The West Gold Hill dinosaur made a full turn and crossed its own path.
The earliest surviving silk-scroll painting from Gangwon Province was found in an attic in Hopkinton, New Hampshire.
Hundreds of refugees at a UN humanitarian center in Niger have been protesting conditions there for more than a year.
Roti ran 42 restaurants before the COVID-19 pandemic reduced the midday lunch demand.
The Epson MX-80 was the best-selling dot-matrix printer during its market lifespan.
The genetic lines of Poecilia koperi and P. wandae blur in areas where they meet, likely due to occasional hybridization.
Cūḷāmaṇi Cetiya is believed in Buddhist cosmology to enshrine both the Buddha's topknot and his right canine tooth.
A Genshin Impact character (Wanderer) was inspired by the Queen song 'Bohemian Rhapsody'.
A Stradivarius cello once owned by Ernest de Munck is now named after him.
The 1979 computer chess game Chesmac could not display a chessboard on screen, so players had to replicate the game on a physical chessboard.
MyRadar uses a custom satellite constellation to help forecast the weather.
A 1920s reviewer considered Hammond's Hard Lines 'dangerously experimental ground for boys' fiction'.
The Littlehampton libels saw Edith Swan fool three juries and two judges, have another woman sent to prison twice, and be declared not guilty before finally being convicted.
One 1886 night, 150 people broke into a courthouse and began moving it 15 miles (24 km), before getting stuck in a blizzard.
A nuclear reactor was nearly built at the New York Hall of Science, but the money instead went to Yankee Stadium.
A US$10,000 bill is the highest denomination of US currency that has been used by the public.
Americans received nearly 15 billion political text messages in 2022.
The US Air Force considered a bomber version of the F-22 Raptor known as the FB-22.
Martha Washington's portrait on the 1896 US one-dollar silver certificate is the most recent time that a woman has been featured on US paper money.
38 per cent of Welsh university students in 1900 were women.
The style of Hermann Weyl's Gruppentheorie und Quantenmechanik has been likened to 'a smiling figure on horseback, cutting a clean way through ... with a swift bright sword'.
The author of The Power of Babel says that speakers of Swedish, Norwegian, and Danish are all speaking the same language.
Between 1899 and 1923 the United States government issued 3,604,239,600 one-dollar Black Eagle Silver Certificates.
The Shrine of Taharqa was coated in nitrocellulose.
According to tradition, Saint Ludger healed the Frisian bard Bernlef of his blindness and taught him to play psalms on his harp.
The flag of Duluth, Minnesota has an award-winning simple design, but still represents eight things including Lake Superior, the North Woods, and three city hills.
Vollpension employs grandparents to bake cakes according to their own recipes and, during COVID-19, offered live baking courses from elders around the world.
Storm Ulysses in 1903 was so named because its effects were described in James Joyce's novel Ulysses.
A class-action lawsuit was filed against Spotify following the discontinuation of the Car Thing.
During the Tunisian campaign in World War II, crews carried an AMES Type 6 radar set across a swamp to spy on Luftwaffe aircraft.
The electrification of the Midland Main Line was designated as a high priority in 1981, but work to electrify the northern part did not begin until more than 30 years later.
The children's museum La Nube includes a bus-washing exhibit.
Alexander McQueen's collection Voss included dresses made from razor clams, microscope slides, and an antique Japanese folding screen.
Zhong Jingwen was known as the 'father of Chinese folklore studies'.
The British Army's Submarine Mining Service defended ports and harbours with naval mines and torpedoes.
Thomas Broun has been blamed for inflating the number of beetle species in New Zealand.
Café Adria survived a hit by a Karl-Gerät siege mortar.
The borders of the Yellow River Delta National Nature Reserve were drawn to minimize impact on the Shengli Oil Field.
Electriquette was an electric wicker vehicle that could be rented at the 1915 Panama–California Exposition.
Tokamak de Fontenay-aux-Roses burned a hole through itself shortly after completion in a plasma disruption.
19th-century Polish writer Józef Ignacy Kraszewski authored hundreds of works, including more than 200 novels.
The legalization of abortion in Benin was supported by two members of the cabinet who had both worked as gynecologists.
Many producers of Marmelada de Santa Luzia, a variety of quince cheese, are descendants of quilombolas.
Austin J. Tobin Plaza was destroyed in the September 11 attacks, but one of the sculptures on it (The Sphere) survived.
Up to 16,000 crows regularly commute from around the Seattle metropolitan area to a wetland in Bothell, Washington.
Ivan the Terrible (film) has been named as both one of the worst films and one of the greatest films of all time.
30 royal portraits of Korean kings were completely destroyed in a 1954 fire in Busan, South Korea.
